item.title: MelissaTerras on "Good books relevant to DH in the past year?"
item.dc:creator: MelissaTerras
item.description:
Hi Folks,

I'm back to work after a year-long career break next month. Although I've kept up to date with online blogs, twitter, etc, I havent read any books related to DH in the past year, and wondered if you had any recommendations. What books have you read that really grabbed you and would be worth exploring?

I'm interested in anything related to DH, Internet Technologies, Cultural Heritage, and online communities. What is worth investigating? What's the best thing you've read in the past year? I'd appreciate any of your heads-up. Thanks.

Melissa

item.title: Bethany Nowviskie on "Reading recommendations for a GIS newbie?"
item.dc:creator: Bethany Nowviskie
item.description:
And a GIS newbie in the digital humanities might want to start here:
http://spatial.scholarslab.org/
-- an NEH-funded, community-driven "Spatial Humanities" site from the Scholar's Lab, just launched today!

It includes some great essays by Jo Guldi framing the "spatial turn" across the disciplines, and a nascent, peer-reviewed set of step-by-step tutorials -- as well as a variety of crowdsourced resources drawn from Zotero groups, hashtags, and sites like... DH Answers! :)

item.title: saschmidt8 on "Reading recommendations for a GIS newbie?"
item.dc:creator: saschmidt8
item.description:
Hi Eric

I'd recommend the following books and taking a look at the bibliography and resources pages on the HGIS website

http://www.hgis.org.uk/bibliography.htm

http://www.hgis.org.uk/resources.htm

Gregory, Ian N. and Paul S. Ell. Historical GIS: Technologies, Methodologies, and Scholarship. Cambridge Studies in Historical Geography. 2007

Sinton, Diana Stuart and Jennifer J. Lund Understanding Place: GIS and Mapping Across the Curriculm ESRI Press, 2006.

Also though I haven't had a chance to read it yet, I think the following book may also be of interest

Bodenhamer, David J. et al The Spatial Humanities: GIS and the Future of Humanities Scholarship Indiana U. Press, 2010

Sara Schmidt

item.title: Alex Galarza on "Reading recommendations for a GIS newbie?"
item.dc:creator: Alex Galarza
item.description:
Replying to @Kelly Johnston's post:

I found this post very helpful to wet my beak with some reading. After reading from a few of your links, I was wondering if you might be able to answer a follow-up question: My adviser asked if I was familiar enough with GIS to produce maps for his manuscript, to which I replied no. Is there a standard for historians and anthropologists using GIS to produce maps for their books? Is it qGIS? Should I start with qGIS and move onto something else if I want to do my own maps for my own dissertation in the years to come? Thanks!

item.title: Kelly Johnston on "Reading recommendations for a GIS newbie?"
item.dc:creator: Kelly Johnston
item.description:
Hi Eric,

A few suggestions:
An engaging mappy introduction to GIS and its application: Maptogether

David Rumsey’s take on historical maps in GIS: Rumsey

A gentle (and excellent) introduction to GIS with examples using qGIS, one of the best free open source GIS packages: qGIS

Real world issues of cartography and presentation: Cartographic Perspectives

Librarians' lists of best GIS resources: Top 5 GIS Resources

The Bigger Picture: Maps are not the world, they are propositions: This Is Not The World

Kelly Johnston

item.title: Eric Johnson on "Reading recommendations for a GIS newbie?"
item.dc:creator: Eric Johnson
item.description:
I had a fantastic introduction to GIS at Friday's BootCamp at THATCamp Virginia. Are there any books you would recommend to help orient someone very enthusiastic about but new to GIS?

I just snagged Anne Knowles' Placing History : How Maps, Spatial Data, and GIS are Changing Historical Scholarship out of the library here, but that's focused of course on a specific kind of application of GIS.

Any and all advice is definitely very welcome!

item.title: Mats Dahlstrom on "What are the essential DH books on your class reading list?"
item.dc:creator: Mats Dahlstrom
item.description:
In addition to those already mentioned, I would add:

Burnard, Lou, O'Brien O'Keeffe, Katherine & Unsworth. John, eds. (2006). Electronic textual editing. New York: MLA/TEI. http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/ETE/Preview/index.xml

Shillingsburg, Peter (2006). From Gutenberg to Google: electronic representations of literary texts. Cambridge: Cambridge UP.

Sutherland, Kathryn & Deegan, Marilyn (2009). Transferred illusions: Digital technology and the forms of print. London: Ashgate.

Terras, Melissa (2008). Digital Images for the Information Professional. London: Ashgate.

A promising item to be issued the upcoming year is:
van der Weel, Adriaan (2011). Changing Our Textual Minds: Towards a Digital Order of Knowledge. Manchester UP.

An instructive case of library digitisation students can look at is:
National Library of Australia (2010). Collection Digitisation Overview.
Available through http://www.nla.gov.au/digital/index.html

item.title: Aurelien Berra on "What are the essential DH books on your class reading list?"
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Berra
item.description:
I definitely would recommend Willard McCarty's stimulating views:
- Willard McCarty, "Humanities Computing", Houndmills, Basingstoke, Palgrave Macmillan, 2005.
- Willard McCarty, "Attending from and to the machine", Inaugural Lecture, Centre for Computing in the Humanities, King's College, London, 2010.

Classics being a dynamic field in which general DH questions are discussed, I think the following reference could be suggested (even by one the editors of the book?):
- Melissa Terras & Gregory Crane (ed.), "Changing the Center of Gravity. Transforming Classical Studies Through Cyberinfrastructure", Piscataway, Gorgias Press, 2010.
Along the same lines, Alison Babeu's CLIR report "Rome Wasn't Digitized in a Day: Building a Cyberinfrastructure for Digital Classicists" will be extremely relevant in its final form.
